title: Quiz 1: Road Signs and Markings
description: Test your knowledge of Kenyan road signs, traffic signals, and road markings

question.value: What does a red octagonal sign mean?

media.caption: A red octagonal road sign on a white post

questions.explanation: A red octagonal (8-sided) sign is universally recognised as a STOP sign. You must come to a complete stop before the line and check that it is safe to proceed.
questions.hint: Count the sides of the shape — what does that number suggest?

context.value:
Road Sign Shapes

Different shapes help drivers recognise sign categories instantly, even at speed or in poor visibility.

  • Octagon (8 sides) — Critical regulatory signs
  • Triangle — Warning signs
  • Circle — Regulatory instructions
  • Rectangle — Information and guidance

question.value: What does a triangular sign with a red border mean?

media.caption: Triangular road sign with red border

questions.explanation: Triangular signs with red borders are warning signs. They alert drivers to potential hazards ahead — such as sharp bends, pedestrian crossings, or animal crossings.
questions.hint: These signs prepare you for what lies ahead — they are not commands.

context.value:
Sign Shapes and Colours

Road signs use consistent shapes and colours so drivers can categorise a sign before reading its detail.

  • Triangle (pointing up) — Red border, white background: warning
  • Circle with red border — Prohibition
  • Circle with blue background — Mandatory instruction
  • Rectangle — Various colours: information

question.value: What does a circular sign with a red border and a diagonal line through it mean?

media.caption: Circular sign with red border and diagonal line

questions.explanation: A red circle with a diagonal line (slash) indicates prohibition — something is not permitted. The symbol inside shows what is prohibited, for example a horn symbol means no sounding of horns.
questions.hint: The diagonal line means 'no' or 'not allowed' — like a universal cancel symbol.

context.value:
Red on Road Signs

Red is used internationally to communicate critical rules and restrictions. On Kenyan roads you will see red used in three ways:

  • Red octagon — STOP sign
  • Red triangle border — Hazard warning
  • Red circle with diagonal — Prohibition (no doing X)
  • Red circle border only — Speed limit or other restriction

questions.question: What does a blue circular sign indicate?

options.text: A mandatory instruction you must obey

questions.explanation: Blue circular signs give mandatory instructions that must be obeyed by law. Common examples include 'turn left ahead', 'keep right', and 'minimum speed' signs.
questions.hint: Blue circles tell you what you MUST do — not what to avoid.

context.value:
Mandatory vs Prohibition Signs

Both use circular shapes but are easy to tell apart:

  • Blue circle — Mandatory: you must do this
  • Red circle with diagonal — Prohibition: you must not do this
  • Red circle border only — Restriction: e.g. speed limit

Ignoring a mandatory sign is a traffic offence under the Traffic Act of Kenya.

questions.question: A broken white line on the road means you may cross it to overtake if it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A broken (dashed) white centre line is a lane separator and may be crossed to overtake when it is safe. A solid white line must not be crossed.
questions.hint: Think about what a 'gap' in a line implies — can something pass through a gap?

context.value:
Road Centre-Line Markings

questions.question: What does a continuous yellow line painted at the edge of the road mean?
questions.explanation: A continuous yellow kerb line means no parking at any time. You may stop briefly to drop off or pick up passengers, but you cannot leave the vehicle unattended.
questions.hint: Yellow edge lines are always about parking — the type of line tells you how strict the restriction is.

context.value:
Yellow Kerb Line Rules

Line TypeRestrictionWhen
Single yellowNo parkingSpecific hours (check nearby sign)
Double yellowNo parkingAt any time
Continuous yellowNo parking24 hours, 7 days

question.value: What must you do when you see a yellow (amber) traffic light?

media.caption: Understanding traffic light signals and proper response

options.text: Accelerate to clear the junction before it turns red
Stop if you can do so safely

questions.explanation: A yellow light means stop if you can do so safely. It warns that the signal is about to turn red. Accelerating to 'beat' a yellow light is dangerous and may constitute running a red light if you cross after it has changed.
questions.hint: Yellow is a transition warning — what comes immediately after it?

context.value:
Traffic Light Sequence in Kenya

  • Red — Stop. Do not proceed.
  • Red + Yellow together — Prepare to move; engine on, foot on clutch.
  • Green — Proceed if the way is clear.
  • Yellow (alone) — Stop if safe to do so; light is about to turn red.

Note: Not all Kenyan junctions use the red+yellow combination phase.

questions.question: Which of the following are officially recognised categories of road signs? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The four recognised categories are Warning, Prohibition, Mandatory, and Information signs. 'Suggestion signs' is not an official category — road signs are legally binding, not advisory.
questions.hint: Think about the four main shapes and colours you see on Kenyan roads.

context.value:

questions.question: What does a white 'X' painted on the road surface warn drivers about?
questions.explanation: A white X on the road surface warns of a railway level crossing ahead. You should reduce speed, listen for approaching trains, and be prepared to stop.
questions.hint: This marking is placed before a point where another type of transport crosses the road.

context.value:
Road Surface Markings

Road surface markings supplement signs and signals. Some common Kenyan examples:

  • White X — Railway level crossing ahead
  • White zigzag lines — Pedestrian crossing zone; no overtaking or parking
  • Yellow box marking — Keep clear; only enter if your exit is clear
  • White arrows — Direction of travel; lane guidance

questions.question: What does a circular sign showing two cars side by side mean?
questions.explanation: A circular sign showing two cars side by side (one black, one red) prohibits overtaking. It is placed in sections where overtaking is particularly dangerous, such as on bends or near junctions.
questions.hint: The sign shows two vehicles at the same position — think about what that action is called.

context.value:
Prohibition Signs — Common Examples

  • No overtaking — Two cars side by side
  • No U-turn — Curved arrow with diagonal
  • No horn — Horn symbol with diagonal
  • No entry — White horizontal bar on red circle
  • Speed limit — Number inside red circle

questions.question: A police officer at a junction is facing you with both arms outstretched sideways. What must you do?

options.text: Proceed — the officer is signalling you to go
Stop — traffic facing the officer's front and back must halt
Hoot to get the officer's attention

questions.explanation: When a police officer faces you with arms extended to each side, you are facing the officer's front. Traffic facing the front or back of the officer must stop. Only traffic facing the officer's side (left or right) may proceed.
questions.hint: The officer acts like a traffic light — which direction is the officer's 'front' facing?

context.value:
Police Officer Hand Signals

  • Officer facing you, arms out sideways — Stop. You are in the STOP direction.
  • Officer's side facing you, arms out — Proceed. You are in the GO direction.
  • Officer raises right hand (palm out) — All traffic must stop.
  • Officer beckons with right hand — Traffic from that direction may proceed.

Police signals override all other traffic signs and signals.

questions.question: White zigzag lines painted on the road near a pedestrian crossing mean you must not park or overtake in that area.
questions.explanation: White zigzag lines mark the approach to and exit from a pedestrian crossing. Parking and overtaking are prohibited in this zone to ensure pedestrians can be seen clearly by drivers.
questions.hint: Zigzag lines are designed to protect a specific type of road user — which one?

context.value:
Pedestrian Crossing Zones

Kenyan roads use several types of pedestrian crossing markings:

  • Zebra crossing — Black and white stripes; pedestrians have priority
  • White zigzag lines — No parking, no overtaking in this zone
  • Pelican crossing — Controlled by push-button traffic signals

Always approach pedestrian crossings at a controlled speed.

questions.question: A speed limit sign shows the number 50 inside a red circle. What does this mean?

options.text: The recommended speed on this road is 50 km/h
The maximum speed permitted is 50 km/h
The minimum speed on this road is 50 km/h

questions.explanation: A number inside a red circle is a maximum speed limit sign. You must not exceed that speed. In Kenya, urban areas are typically limited to 50 km/h, with higher limits on highways.
questions.hint: Numbers inside red circles are always about speed — and red means restriction.

context.value:

Road TypeLimit

Expressway110 km/h

question.value:
Study the road marking descriptions below:

MarkingDescription
ASolid white line on the left edge of the road
BBroken white line in the centre of the road
CSolid yellow line on the left kerb

Which marking prohibits parking at any time?

questions.explanation: Marking C — the solid yellow kerb line — indicates no parking at any time. Marking A is the road edge boundary. Marking B is a lane separator that may be crossed to overtake.
questions.hint: One of these markings is a kerb (edge) restriction — which colour signals parking rules?

questions.question: What does a triangular sign showing a silhouette of two children mean?

options.text: School ahead — reduce speed and be prepared to stop
Playground — children may not cross here
No children allowed beyond this point

questions.explanation: A triangular warning sign with children silhouettes indicates a school zone or area where children frequently cross. You must reduce speed and be prepared to stop.
questions.hint: It is a triangle — so it is a warning about something ahead. Who does it depict?

context.value:
School Zone Rules in Kenya

  • Reduce speed when approaching a school zone sign
  • Watch for children crossing from between parked vehicles
  • Do not park on zigzag lines or block pedestrian crossings near schools
  • Be especially alert during school arrival and dismissal times

questions.question: You are waiting at a red traffic light. The light changes to green. What should you do?

options.text: Move off immediately at full speed
Wait for the car behind to hoot, then proceed
Check that the junction is clear, then proceed
Sound your horn to warn pedestrians, then go

questions.explanation: A green light permits you to proceed, but you must first ensure the junction is clear. Other vehicles or pedestrians may still be clearing the junction from the previous phase. Always observe before moving.
questions.hint: Green means permission to go — but permission does not remove the duty to observe.

context.value:
Green Light — Proceed with Observation

A green signal gives you the right of way, but it does not guarantee safety. Before moving:

  • Check for vehicles that have run the red from crossing traffic
  • Check for pedestrians still crossing
  • Check your mirrors before pulling away

questions.question: Which of the following actions are prohibited in a yellow box junction? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Entering the box if your exit road is blocked
Turning right while waiting for oncoming traffic to clear
Stopping inside the box due to queuing traffic ahead

questions.explanation: In a yellow box junction you must not enter unless your exit is clear, park inside it, or stop due to queuing — all of which block other traffic. The one exception is turning right: you may wait inside the box for a gap in oncoming traffic, provided your exit is clear.
questions.hint: The purpose of a box junction is to keep it clear at all times — with one specific exception.

context.value:
Yellow Box Junction Rule

The rule is simple: do not enter the box unless your exit road is clear.

The single exception: when turning right, you may enter the box and wait for oncoming traffic to pass — as long as your exit is not blocked by queuing vehicles.

questions.question: A sign showing a white horizontal bar on a red circle means 'No Entry'.
questions.explanation: The 'No Entry' sign is a white horizontal rectangle (bar) on a red circle. It is placed on one-way streets and restricted access roads to prevent vehicles from entering from the wrong direction.
questions.hint: Think about what a solid barrier (horizontal bar) inside a prohibition circle would mean.

context.value:
No Entry vs Do Not Enter vs Wrong Way

These three concepts are communicated by different signs, sometimes used together:

  • No Entry (red circle + white bar) — Do not enter this road from this direction
  • Wrong Way sign — You are already travelling in the wrong direction; turn around
  • One Way sign — Informs drivers of the direction of travel on that road

questions.question: What does a green rectangular sign on a Kenyan road typically provide?
questions.explanation: Green rectangular signs are directional information signs. They show destinations, distances, and route numbers, helping drivers navigate. Blue rectangular signs serve a similar purpose in urban areas.
questions.hint: Green is the colour associated with 'go' and guidance — not restriction or warning.

context.value:
Information Sign Colours in Kenya

  • Green rectangle — Highway / inter-city directions and distances
  • Blue rectangle — Urban directions, motorway information, services
  • White rectangle — Local destinations, tourist routes
  • Brown rectangle — Tourist attractions and heritage sites
